title: Maria Grazia Chiuri Talks To ELLE About Creating 'Rebirth' Through Plants And Nature, For Dior SS20
text:
From ELLE

Nothing short of spellbinding, Dior has long had a reputation for putting on some of the best fashion shows of the season.

Whether it's a brigade of real horses for Cruise, or a rioting runway, inspired by the youth revolts of 1968 - Maria Grazia Chiuri knows how to captivate her audiences, drawing attention, not just to that season's collection, but also to some greater political issue or tapping into a cultural consciousness.

This September, for the Dior SS20 runway, Chiuri went a step beyond previous years, taking her show's set to Chanel-level immersive theatre proportions.

Photo credit: Andrea Adriani/Imaxtree.com - Imaxtree More

A nod both to the fashion house's horticultural heritage and also to the current climate crisis, opted to stage the runway in the middle of a secret woodland garden, with the models walking between trees that were later to be re-purposed as part of a re-forestation effort.

Speaking behind the scenes ahead of the collection's catwalk debut, Chiuri explains the pressure to 'better reflect on and present the future.'

But she also insists that the evolution of her designs comes in part from her ever deepening knowledge of the French fashion house's heritage. For the SS20 season, Chiuri felt moved in particular by the story of Christian Dior's sister Catherine Dior.

Photo credit: Matteo Scarpellini - Imaxtree More

Catherine, she divulges, lived a tough life, but through plants 'managed to experience a rebirth.'

Part of her intention, she explains in the video, is to transform the house's heritage into an action for the future, bringing the story full circle.
